lifewayscacao:cacao101-title: Cacao 101: How I Learned to Stop Worrying and Love Chocolate
lifewayscacao:cacao101-text:
Cacao 101
Did you know making chocolate has a lot of steps?

Obtaining Cacao
Cacao comes from the cacao tree (obviously), which you can find in very warm and very rainy climates. They won't give you anything immediately useable like other fruit trees, though - instead, they grow big, hard cacao pods, which you'll have to crack open by holding them in your hand, then pressing and holding rightmouse, which will give you pulpy cacao beans.

Processing Those Beans
The pulpy cacao beans you get from cracking open a pod aren't very useful in and of themselves - you can either eat the mucilage off them the same way you'd eat any other food, in which case you'll spit out the raw cacao beans.

Or, you can put them in your crafting grid to separate the mucilage manually, giving you cacao mucilage and raw cacao beans. Once separated, cacao mucilage is like any other fruit in the game - you can eat it, use it in meals, press it in the fruitpress, etc.

The beans, separated from the mucilage, aren't very useful on their own - they're bad-tasting and only give a small amount of protein nutrition. In order to make them more appetizing and nutritious, we need to ferment them!

Fermenting Cacao Beans
Cacao beans don't take much to ferment - the mucilage is a good enough fermentation base! Either put the pulpy cacao beans in a barrel by themselves, or add the cacao mucilage and then the raw cacao beans, in a 1:4 ratio - the latter method is more efficient, but requires additional work!

Then, simply seal the barrel and wait.

Drying Beans
The fermented cacao beans are kinda gross, and prone to spoiling. In order to make them last longer, you can dry them out, either by leaving them in the open in cool, dry conditions, or roasting them over a fire, getting you dried cacao beans!

Making Chocolate
You can make cacao nibs by grinding those dried cacao beans in a quern, which really brings out the flavor and nutrition, and gives a small healing effect! More advanced chocolate-making to come in future updates.
lifewayscacao:item-handbooktext-cacaopod: In order to crack open a cacao pod and extract the pulpy cacao beans inside, simply hold it in your hand and press and hold rightmouse.
lifewayscacao:item-handbooktext-cacaobea: In order to obtain cacao beans in their pulpy form, you extract them from a cacao pod by holding it in your hand and pressing and holding rightmouse.

Cacao beans aren't all that useful in their initial form. You can eat the sweet cacao mucilage off the beans by eating them normally, which will give you raw cacao beans as you spit out the bitter, acidic beans; or you can manually separate the mucilage by placing them in your crafting grid, which will allow you to use it in meals, press it for juice, or any of the other things you normally do with fruit!

The beans themselves can be made much more appetizing and nutritious by fermenting them. No non-cacao ingredients are required: simply place pulpy cacao beans in a barrel and seal it, or separate the cacao mucilage from the raw cacao beans in your crafting grid and place them both in the barrel (in a slightly more efficient ratio than without separating the mucilage)!
